medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Nonhealing decubitus ulcer, left ischial region? Osteomyelitis, paraplegia, and history of spina bifida. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Nonhealing decubitus ulcer, left ischial region? Osteomyelitis, paraplegia, and history of spina bifida. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Debridement left ischial ulcer. ANESTHESIA: Local MAC. INDICATIONS: This is a 27-year-old white male patient, with a history of spina bifida who underwent spinal surgery about two years ago and subsequently he has been paraplegic. The patient has a nonhealing decubitus ulcer in the left ischial region, which is quite deep. It appears to be right down to the bone. MRI shows findings suggestive of osteomyelitis. The patient is being brought to operating room for debridement of this ulcer. Procedure, indication, and risks were explained to the patient. Consent obtained. PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was put in right lateral position and left buttock and ischial region was prepped and draped. Examination at this time showed fair amount of chronic granulation tissue and scarred tissue circumferentially as well as the base of this decubitus ulcer. This was sharply excised until bleeding and healthy tissue was obtained circumferentially as well as the base. The ulcer does not appear to be going into the bone itself as there was a covering on the bone, which appears to be quite healthy, normal and bone itself appeared solid. I did not rongeur the bone. The deeper portion of the excised tissue was also sent for tissue cultures. Hemostasis was achieved with cautery and the wound was irrigated with sterile saline solution and then packed with medicated Kerlix. Sterile dressing was applied. The patient transferred to recovery room in stable condition.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Nonhealing pressure sore on the left buttock, bone infection (osteomyelitis), paralysis of the lower body (paraplegia), and a history of spina bifida.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Same as above.  

PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Removal of dead tissue from the left buttock pressure sore.  

ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia (MAC).  

INDICATIONS: A 27‑year‑old white man with spina bifida who had spinal surgery two years ago and is now paraplegic. He has a deep, nonhealing pressure sore on the left buttock that reaches the bone. An MRI shows signs of bone infection. He was taken to the operating room to clean out the sore. The procedure, reasons, and possible risks were explained, and he gave his consent.  

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was positioned on his right side. The left buttock area was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. The surgeon saw a lot of old scar tissue and new tissue around the sore. The sore was cut away sharply until healthy, bleeding tissue was reached around the edges and at the bottom. The bone was not involved; it looked healthy and solid, so no bone was removed. Tissue from the deeper part of the sore was sent for culture. Bleeding was stopped with cautery. The wound was washed with sterile saline and filled with medicated gauze (Kerlix). A sterile dressing was applied. The patient was moved to the recovery room in stable condition.
